items.title: I can describe the structure of an atom and identify the charges of its components
items.what: Atoms consist of a nucleus containing protons (positive charge) and neutrons (no charge), with electrons (negative charge) orbiting around the nucleus.
items.why: Understanding atomic structure explains where electric charge comes from and why some materials conduct electricity while others do not.
items.example: A copper atom has 29 protons in its nucleus (each with charge +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) and 29 electrons orbiting it (each with charge -1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C), making the atom electrically neutral overall.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can model a metal conductor as a lattice of positive ions in a sea of free electrons
items.what: In metals, the outer electrons are not bound to any particular atom but move freely through the material, creating a 'sea' of electrons around fixed positive ions.
items.why: This model explains why metals conduct electricity well and helps visualise how current flows when a potential difference is applied.
items.example: In a copper wire, each copper atom releases one or more outer electrons that can move freely. The remaining atoms form positive ions fixed in a crystal lattice structure.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can describe electric current as the drift of electrons and distinguish between electron flow and conventional current
items.what: Current is the net flow of electric charge. In metals, electrons drift slowly (about 0.1 mm/s) toward the positive terminal. Conventional current is defined as flowing from positive to negative, opposite to electron flow.
items.why: The distinction matters because circuit analysis uses conventional current direction, even though we know electrons actually move the opposite way.
items.example: When a battery is connected, electrons drift from the negative terminal through the wire toward the positive terminal at about 0.1 mm/s. We say conventional current flows from positive to negative.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can distinguish between conductors, insulators, and semiconductors
items.what: Conductors have many free electrons and allow current to flow easily. Insulators have few or no free electrons. Semiconductors conduct partially or under certain conditions.
items.why: Choosing the right materials is essential for building safe and functional electrical devices, from wiring to electronic components.
items.example: Copper wire (conductor) is used for electrical wiring because electrons flow freely. Plastic coating (insulator) surrounds the wire for safety. Silicon (semiconductor) is used in computer chips.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can use circuit symbols to draw and interpret circuit diagrams
items.what: Standard circuit symbols represent components like batteries, resistors, switches, and meters. Circuit diagrams show how components are connected without needing to draw realistic pictures.
items.why: Circuit diagrams provide a universal language that scientists and engineers worldwide can understand, making it possible to communicate designs clearly.
items.example: A battery is shown as two parallel lines (one longer than the other), a resistor as a rectangle, and an ammeter as a circle with 'A' inside. A simple torch circuit shows these connected in a loop.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can use an ammeter correctly to measure current in a circuit
items.what: An ammeter measures current in amperes (A) and must be connected in series so all the current flows through it. The unit 1 A equals 1 coulomb of charge per second.
items.why: Measuring current accurately is essential for testing circuits, troubleshooting problems, and ensuring components receive the correct current.
items.example: To measure the current through a light bulb, break the circuit and insert the ammeter so the current flows through it. If the ammeter reads 0.5 A, then 0.5 coulombs of charge pass through it every second.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can apply the formula I = Q/t to calculate current, charge, or time
items.what: Current (I) equals charge (Q) divided by time (t). This can be rearranged to find Q = It or t = Q/I. Current is measured in amperes (A), charge in coulombs (C), and time in seconds (s).
items.why: This formula connects the amount of charge flowing to how long it flows and at what rate, which is fundamental to understanding and designing circuits.
items.example: If a current of 2 A flows for 30 seconds, the total charge is Q = It = 2 × 30 = 60 C. This means 60 coulombs of charge (about 3.75 × 10²⁰ electrons) passed through the circuit.

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can use analogies to explain charge and current in a circuit
items.what: Analogies like a bicycle chain or water flow help explain electrical concepts. The chain links represent electrons, the pedals represent the battery, and the rear wheel represents the load.
items.why: Analogies make abstract electrical concepts more concrete and help build intuition, though all analogies have limitations.
items.example: In the bicycle chain analogy, when you start pedalling, every link in the chain moves immediately (like current flowing instantly throughout a circuit), even though individual links move slowly (like electron drift velocity).

subtopic.name: Charge and Current
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of electric charge and current, including atomic structure, the behaviour of electrons in conductors, and how to measure and calculate current in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding charge and current is essential because these concepts form the foundation of all electrical systems. From smartphones to electric vehicles, every electrical device relies on the controlled movement of charge.

items.title: I can explain that separating charges creates potential difference and requires energy input
items.what: When positive and negative charges are separated, electrical potential energy is stored. Batteries use chemical reactions to separate charges, while generators use kinetic energy.
items.why: Understanding charge separation explains how all electrical energy sources work, from simple batteries to solar panels and power stations.
items.example: In a 9 V battery, chemical reactions separate positive and negative charges to the two terminals. This separation stores energy that can do 9 joules of work for every coulomb of charge that flows through a circuit.

subtopic.name: Energy and Potential Difference
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can define potential difference as energy per unit charge and apply V = E/Q
items.what: Potential difference (V) is the energy (E) transferred per coulomb of charge (Q). It is measured in volts, where 1 V = 1 J/C. The formula can be rearranged to E = QV.
items.why: This relationship shows that both the amount of charge and the potential difference determine the total energy transferred in a circuit.
items.example: A 12 V car battery supplies 12 joules of energy for every coulomb of charge. If 500 C flows through the circuit, the total energy supplied is E = QV = 500 × 12 = 6000 J.

subtopic.name: Energy and Potential Difference
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can apply E = VIt to calculate electrical energy in a circuit
items.what: Combining V = E/Q with I = Q/t gives E = VIt. This formula calculates the energy transferred when current I flows through a potential difference V for time t.
items.why: This formula is practical because V and I can be measured directly with meters, making it easy to calculate energy consumption of appliances.
items.example: A phone charger operates at 5 V with 2 A current for 2 hours (7200 s). The energy delivered is E = VIt = 5 × 2 × 7200 = 72,000 J = 72 kJ.

subtopic.name: Energy and Potential Difference
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can use a voltmeter correctly to measure potential difference
items.what: A voltmeter measures potential difference in volts and must be connected in parallel across a component. It compares the energy per charge entering and leaving the component.
items.why: Measuring potential difference tells us how much energy each coulomb of charge transfers to or from a component, which is essential for circuit analysis.
items.example: To measure the potential difference across a light bulb, connect the voltmeter leads to either side of the bulb without breaking the circuit. A reading of 6 V means each coulomb loses 6 J of energy in the bulb.

subtopic.name: Energy and Potential Difference
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can distinguish between the positioning of an ammeter (series) and voltmeter (parallel)
items.what: Ammeters go in series because they must measure all charge flowing through. Voltmeters go in parallel because they compare energy at two points without interrupting current flow.
items.why: Incorrect meter placement gives wrong readings and can damage meters. Understanding why each meter is placed differently helps avoid these errors.
items.example: To test a light bulb circuit: break the circuit and insert the ammeter so all current flows through it (series). Connect the voltmeter across the bulb without breaking the circuit (parallel).

subtopic.name: Energy and Potential Difference
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can use analogies to explain potential difference and energy transfer in circuits
items.what: The bowling ball analogy shows balls gaining gravitational potential energy when lifted (like charge gaining electrical energy from a battery) and losing it when falling through liquid (like energy transfer in components).
items.why: Gravitational analogies help visualise the abstract concept of electrical potential energy, making it easier to understand how energy flows in circuits.
items.example: In the waterfall analogy, water height represents potential difference. A 12 m waterfall (12 V battery) gives each kilogram of water (coulomb of charge) 12 times more energy than a 1 m waterfall (1 V battery).

subtopic.name: Energy and Potential Difference
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
subtopic.why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can define resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current
items.what: Resistance (R) equals potential difference (V) divided by current (I). The unit of resistance is the ohm (Ω), where 1 Ω = 1 V/A.
items.why: Resistance quantifies how much a component opposes current flow, which is essential information for selecting components and designing circuits.
items.example: A light bulb with 12 V across it and 0.5 A flowing through it has resistance R = V/I = 12/0.5 = 24 Ω. This tells us the bulb opposes current flow moderately.

subtopic.name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers electrical resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current, Ohm's law for ohmic conductors, and how to analyse I-V characteristic graphs.
subtopic.why: Resistance determines how much current flows for a given potential difference. Understanding resistance and Ohm's law is essential for designing circuits that function correctly and safely.

items.title: I can apply Ohm's law (V = IR) to solve circuit problems
items.what: Ohm's law states V = IR, which can be rearranged to I = V/R or R = V/I. This allows calculation of any quantity when the other two are known.
items.why: Ohm's law is the fundamental equation for circuit analysis, allowing prediction of how changing one quantity affects the others.
items.example: A 1000 Ω resistor is connected to a 9 V battery. The current is I = V/R = 9/1000 = 0.009 A = 9 mA. If the battery voltage doubles, the current also doubles to 18 mA.

subtopic.name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers electrical resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current, Ohm's law for ohmic conductors, and how to analyse I-V characteristic graphs.
subtopic.why: Resistance determines how much current flows for a given potential difference. Understanding resistance and Ohm's law is essential for designing circuits that function correctly and safely.

items.title: I can interpret I-V characteristic graphs and identify ohmic and non-ohmic components
items.what: An I-V graph plots current against potential difference. Ohmic components show a straight line through the origin (constant resistance). Non-ohmic components show curved lines (varying resistance).
items.why: I-V graphs reveal how components behave across different conditions, which is crucial for selecting the right component for a specific application.
items.example: A resistor shows a straight I-V line with gradient 1/R. A light bulb shows a curve that bends over because its resistance increases as it heats up and the filament gets hotter.

subtopic.name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers electrical resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current, Ohm's law for ohmic conductors, and how to analyse I-V characteristic graphs.
subtopic.why: Resistance determines how much current flows for a given potential difference. Understanding resistance and Ohm's law is essential for designing circuits that function correctly and safely.

items.title: I can calculate resistance from the gradient of an I-V graph
items.what: For an I-V graph with I on the y-axis and V on the x-axis, the gradient equals 1/R. Therefore R = 1/gradient = rise/run inverted to run/rise.
items.why: Graphical analysis of experimental data allows determination of resistance even when values fluctuate, by finding the best-fit line.
items.example: An I-V graph shows a straight line passing through (0,0) and (10 V, 2 A). The gradient is 2/10 = 0.2 A/V. Therefore R = 1/0.2 = 5 Ω.

subtopic.name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers electrical resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current, Ohm's law for ohmic conductors, and how to analyse I-V characteristic graphs.
subtopic.why: Resistance determines how much current flows for a given potential difference. Understanding resistance and Ohm's law is essential for designing circuits that function correctly and safely.

items.title: I can describe and construct circuits to obtain I-V data experimentally
items.what: An I-V experiment uses a variable power supply, ammeter in series, and voltmeter in parallel with the test component. Measurements are taken at multiple voltage settings.
items.why: Experimental determination of I-V characteristics is essential for testing components and verifying theoretical predictions.
items.example: Connect a resistor to a variable power supply (0-12 V). Record current and voltage at 2 V intervals. Plot points on an I-V graph. A straight line through the origin confirms ohmic behaviour.

subtopic.name: Resistance and Ohm's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers electrical resistance as the ratio of potential difference to current, Ohm's law for ohmic conductors, and how to analyse I-V characteristic graphs.
subtopic.why: Resistance determines how much current flows for a given potential difference. Understanding resistance and Ohm's law is essential for designing circuits that function correctly and safely.

items.title: I can identify a series circuit and explain that current is the same at all points
items.what: In a series circuit, components are connected in a single path with no branches. The same current flows through every component because there is only one path for electrons.
items.why: Understanding that current is constant in series helps predict circuit behaviour and explains why breaking one part stops the entire circuit.
items.example: In a series circuit with a 6 V battery and two resistors, if an ammeter reads 0.3 A before the first resistor, it will also read 0.3 A between the resistors and after the second resistor.

subtopic.name: Series Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in series circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and the application of potential dividers.
subtopic.why: Series circuits are used in many applications including voltage regulation, sensor circuits, and safety systems. Understanding series behaviour is essential for circuit design and troubleshooting.

items.title: I can explain that potential difference is shared between components in a series circuit
items.what: The sum of potential differences across all components equals the supply voltage: V_supply = V₁ + V₂ + ... + Vₙ. Each component's share depends on its resistance.
items.why: This principle explains how energy is distributed in a circuit and why components with higher resistance receive more energy per charge.
items.example: A 12 V battery powers two resistors in series. If the first resistor has 8 V across it, the second must have 12 - 8 = 4 V across it. The total is always 12 V.

subtopic.name: Series Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in series circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and the application of potential dividers.
subtopic.why: Series circuits are used in many applications including voltage regulation, sensor circuits, and safety systems. Understanding series behaviour is essential for circuit design and troubleshooting.

items.title: I can calculate equivalent resistance in series using R_eq = R₁ + R₂ + ... + Rₙ
items.what: The equivalent resistance of resistors in series is the sum of individual resistances. This single value can replace all the resistors for circuit analysis.
items.why: Calculating equivalent resistance simplifies complex circuits, making it easier to find total current and analyse circuit behaviour.
items.example: Three resistors of 10 Ω, 20 Ω, and 30 Ω in series have equivalent resistance R_eq = 10 + 20 + 30 = 60 Ω. A 12 V battery would produce I = 12/60 = 0.2 A.

subtopic.name: Series Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in series circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and the application of potential dividers.
subtopic.why: Series circuits are used in many applications including voltage regulation, sensor circuits, and safety systems. Understanding series behaviour is essential for circuit design and troubleshooting.

items.title: I can analyse potential divider circuits and calculate output voltage
items.what: A potential divider uses two resistors in series to produce an output voltage that is a fraction of the input. The formula is V_out = V_in × R₂/(R₁ + R₂).
items.why: Potential dividers are used in sensor circuits, volume controls, and anywhere a reduced or adjustable voltage is needed from a fixed supply.
items.example: A 12 V supply connects to a potential divider with R₁ = 3 kΩ and R₂ = 1 kΩ. Output voltage is V_out = 12 × 1000/(3000 + 1000) = 12 × 0.25 = 3 V.

subtopic.name: Series Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in series circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and the application of potential dividers.
subtopic.why: Series circuits are used in many applications including voltage regulation, sensor circuits, and safety systems. Understanding series behaviour is essential for circuit design and troubleshooting.

items.title: I can use I-V graphs to predict equivalent resistance of components in series
items.what: For series components, add the potential differences at each current value to construct the combined I-V graph. The equivalent resistance is found from the new line's gradient.
items.why: Graphical methods allow analysis of non-ohmic components in series, where simple addition of resistances does not apply.
items.example: Two components in series each need 4 V for 1 A of current. In series, the combination needs 4 + 4 = 8 V for 1 A. The equivalent resistance at this point is 8/1 = 8 Ω.

subtopic.name: Series Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in series circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and the application of potential dividers.
subtopic.why: Series circuits are used in many applications including voltage regulation, sensor circuits, and safety systems. Understanding series behaviour is essential for circuit design and troubleshooting.

items.title: I can identify a parallel circuit as one with branches where current splits at junctions
items.what: In a parallel circuit, current has multiple paths. At each junction, current splits into branches and recombines when branches rejoin. Total current equals the sum of branch currents.
items.why: Recognising parallel connections is essential because they behave very differently from series connections in terms of current distribution and equivalent resistance.
items.example: In a circuit with two parallel resistors, 3 A from the battery might split into 2 A through the first resistor and 1 A through the second, then recombine to return 3 A to the battery.

subtopic.name: Parallel Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
subtopic.why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can explain that potential difference is the same across all branches in parallel
items.what: Each branch of a parallel circuit connects directly to the power supply terminals, so every branch experiences the same potential difference regardless of its resistance.
items.why: This property explains why household appliances work correctly when plugged into any outlet - they all receive the same 230 V supply.
items.example: A 12 V battery connected to three parallel resistors provides 12 V across each resistor. A voltmeter placed across any of the three resistors will read 12 V.

subtopic.name: Parallel Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
subtopic.why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can calculate equivalent resistance in parallel using 1/R_eq = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ... + 1/Rₙ
items.what: The reciprocal of equivalent resistance equals the sum of reciprocals of individual resistances. For two resistors, this simplifies to R_eq = (R₁ × R₂)/(R₁ + R₂).
items.why: Parallel equivalent resistance is always less than the smallest individual resistance because adding paths makes it easier for current to flow.
items.example: Two 10 Ω resistors in parallel: R_eq = (10 × 10)/(10 + 10) = 100/20 = 5 Ω. Adding a parallel path halves the equivalent resistance.

subtopic.name: Parallel Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
subtopic.why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can calculate current through each branch of a parallel circuit
items.what: Since each branch has the same potential difference, use I = V/R for each branch separately. The branch with lowest resistance carries the most current.
items.why: Knowing individual branch currents is essential for selecting appropriate wire sizes and ensuring components are not overloaded.
items.example: With 12 V across parallel branches of 6 Ω and 4 Ω: I₁ = 12/6 = 2 A and I₂ = 12/4 = 3 A. Total current from battery is 2 + 3 = 5 A.

subtopic.name: Parallel Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
subtopic.why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can use I-V graphs to predict equivalent resistance of components in parallel
items.what: For parallel components, add the currents at each voltage value to construct the combined I-V graph. The steeper gradient indicates lower equivalent resistance.
items.why: Graphical methods handle non-ohmic components in parallel, allowing analysis of real circuits with varying resistance.
items.example: At 6 V, component A draws 2 A and component B draws 1 A. In parallel at 6 V, total current is 3 A. Equivalent resistance is 6/3 = 2 Ω.

subtopic.name: Parallel Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
subtopic.why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can analyse circuits containing both series and parallel sections
items.what: Complex circuits are simplified by first finding the equivalent resistance of parallel sections, then treating the result as a single resistor in series with other components.
items.why: Most real circuits combine series and parallel elements, so this systematic approach is essential for analysing practical circuits.
items.example: A circuit has a 4 Ω resistor in series with two 8 Ω resistors in parallel. The parallel section has R_eq = 4 Ω. Total resistance is 4 + 4 = 8 Ω.

subtopic.name: Parallel Circuits
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
subtopic.why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can define power as the rate of energy transfer and apply P = E/t
items.what: Power (P) is the rate at which energy is transferred, measured in watts (W). One watt equals one joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s). Power does not depend on duration.
items.why: Power tells us how quickly energy is converted, which determines how fast appliances work and how much current they draw.
items.example: A 2000 W kettle converts 2000 J of electrical energy to thermal energy every second. In 3 minutes (180 s), it transfers E = Pt = 2000 × 180 = 360,000 J = 360 kJ.

subtopic.name: Electric Power
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers power as the rate of energy transfer, formulas for calculating electrical power, and comparison of power in series and parallel circuits.
subtopic.why: Power ratings determine how quickly appliances use energy, affecting electricity costs and component selection. Understanding power is essential for electrical safety and efficiency.

items.title: I can calculate electrical power using P = VI
items.what: Electrical power equals potential difference multiplied by current: P = VI. This formula comes from combining P = E/t with E = VIt.
items.why: This formula is practical because V and I can be measured directly, making it easy to determine power consumption of any electrical device.
items.example: A 230 V appliance drawing 4 A has power P = VI = 230 × 4 = 920 W. This means it converts 920 joules of electrical energy every second.

subtopic.name: Electric Power
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers power as the rate of energy transfer, formulas for calculating electrical power, and comparison of power in series and parallel circuits.
subtopic.why: Power ratings determine how quickly appliances use energy, affecting electricity costs and component selection. Understanding power is essential for electrical safety and efficiency.

items.title: I can apply alternative power formulas P = I²R and P = V²/R
items.what: Substituting from Ohm's law gives P = I²R (useful when current and resistance are known) and P = V²/R (useful when voltage and resistance are known).
items.why: These alternative forms allow power calculation without needing to measure all three quantities, and reveal important relationships in circuit design.
items.example: A 100 Ω resistor carries 0.5 A. Power is P = I²R = 0.5² × 100 = 0.25 × 100 = 25 W. Alternatively, with 50 V across it: P = V²/R = 50²/100 = 2500/100 = 25 W.

subtopic.name: Electric Power
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers power as the rate of energy transfer, formulas for calculating electrical power, and comparison of power in series and parallel circuits.
subtopic.why: Power ratings determine how quickly appliances use energy, affecting electricity costs and component selection. Understanding power is essential for electrical safety and efficiency.

items.title: I can compare power consumption in series and parallel circuits
items.what: Parallel circuits consume more power than series circuits with the same components because parallel connections have lower equivalent resistance and draw more current.
items.why: This comparison explains circuit design choices and why connecting too many devices in parallel can overload a power supply.
items.example: Two 100 Ω resistors with 12 V: In series, R_eq = 200 Ω, P = V²/R = 144/200 = 0.72 W. In parallel, R_eq = 50 Ω, P = 144/50 = 2.88 W - four times more power.

subtopic.name: Electric Power
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers power as the rate of energy transfer, formulas for calculating electrical power, and comparison of power in series and parallel circuits.
subtopic.why: Power ratings determine how quickly appliances use energy, affecting electricity costs and component selection. Understanding power is essential for electrical safety and efficiency.

items.title: I can explain the advantages of parallel circuits for household wiring
items.what: Household circuits use parallel wiring so each appliance receives full voltage, can be switched independently, and continues working if another appliance fails.
items.why: Understanding why homes use parallel circuits explains electrical safety, proper appliance operation, and what happens when circuits are overloaded.
items.example: A TV, lamp, and charger plugged into different outlets all receive 230 V. Turning off the TV does not affect the lamp. If the lamp burns out, the charger still works.

subtopic.name: Electric Power
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers power as the rate of energy transfer, formulas for calculating electrical power, and comparison of power in series and parallel circuits.
subtopic.why: Power ratings determine how quickly appliances use energy, affecting electricity costs and component selection. Understanding power is essential for electrical safety and efficiency.

items.title: I can calculate power loss in connecting wires and explain why low resistance is preferred
items.what: Wires have small resistance that converts some electrical energy to heat. Power loss is P = I²R, so higher currents cause greater losses. Lower resistance wires reduce this waste.
items.why: Minimising power loss in wires improves efficiency, reduces fire risk from overheating, and ensures more energy reaches the intended devices.
items.example: A cable with 0.5 Ω resistance carries 10 A. Power lost as heat is P = I²R = 10² × 0.5 = 50 W. Using 0.1 Ω cable reduces this to just 10 W - an 80% reduction in wasted energy.

subtopic.name: Electric Power
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers power as the rate of energy transfer, formulas for calculating electrical power, and comparison of power in series and parallel circuits.
subtopic.why: Power ratings determine how quickly appliances use energy, affecting electricity costs and component selection. Understanding power is essential for electrical safety and efficiency.
